description: From Middle French remarquer, from Old French remarquer, from re- (“again”) + marquer (“to mark”); see mark.

entries.meaning: An act of pointing out or noticing; notice or observation.
An expression, in speech or writing, of something remarked or noticed; a mention of something
A casual observation, comment, or statement

verbs.description: remark (third-person singular simple present remarks, present participle remarking, simple past and past participle remarked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pay heed to; notice; to take notice of, to perceive. [from 16th c.]
examples: When travelling in Spain, Willkomm remarked qobar at a distance of 3 or 4 miles, yet, on reaching the actual spot, he saw nothing.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To pass comment on (something); to indicate, point out. [16th–18th c.]
examples: [S]he resolved to  […]  enter into conversation with her, by remarking the warmth of the room and the length of the dance.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To mark (someone or something) out; to distinguish, to make notable. [17th c.]
examples: His manacles remark him; there he sits.

entries.meaning: (transitive, with clause as object) To express in words or writing; to state, as an observation. [from 17th c.]
examples: He remarked that it was getting late.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a remark or remarks on, to comment on (something). [from 17th c.]

verbs.description: remark (third-person singular simple present remarks, present participle remarking, simple past and past participle remarked)
